Authors: Dobson, Hannah; Malpas, Charles B.; Burrell, Aidan J. C.; Gurvich, Caroline; Chen, Leo; Kulkarni, Jayashri; Winton-Brown, Toby
Article Title: Burnout and psychological distress amongst Australian healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic
Abstract: Objective: To examine psychological distress in healthcare workers (HCWs) during the COVID-19 pandemic in April-May 2020.Methods: A cross-sectional survey examining demographic, employment and mental health characteristics of HCWs in a large metropolitan hospital in Australia.Results: HCWs showed significant symptoms of moderate-severe level depression (21%), anxiety (20%) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD; 29%), associated with burnout, prior psychiatric history, profession and resilience.Conclusion: Despite low levels of COVID contact, moderate to high levels of psychological distress were reported. Continued monitoring and support for HCWs' mental well-being is warranted as the COVID-19 pandemic develops.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design is a cross-sectional survey, which does not meet the inclusion criteria of a meta-analysis, systematic review of controlled trials, RCTs (including cluster RCTs), or quasi-experimental studies with a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study does not address employment policies and outcomes. It focuses on psychological distress among healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on healthcare workers' psychological distress during the COVID-19 pandemic, not on employment outcomes for people with mental health disorders.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: The study does not directly address employment interventions and does not measure employment outcomes.
